notes.note:
More privacy protections from Enhanced Tracking Protection:

 - [Social tracking protection][1], which blocks cross-site tracking cookies from sites like Facebook, Twitter, and LinkedIn, is now a standard feature of [Enhanced Tracking Protection][2]. <!-- bug 1558341 -->
 - The [Privacy Protections report][3] shows an overview, with details, of the trackers Firefox has blocked. It provides consolidated reports from Monitor and Lockwise. <!-- bug 1549805 -->


  [1]: https://support.mozilla.org/kb/trackers-and-scripts-firefox-blocks-enhanced-track#w_social-media-trackers
  [2]: https://support.mozilla.org/kb/enhanced-tracking-protection-firefox-desktop
  [3]: https://www.mozilla.org/firefox/privacy/products

More security protections from Firefox Lockwise, our digital identity and password management tool:

 - Lockwise for desktop lets you [create, update, and delete][1] your logins and passwords to [sync across all your devices][2], including the Lockwise mobile apps and Firefox mobile browsers . <!-- bug 1549799 -->
 - [Integrated breach alerts][3] from Firefox Monitor, to alert you when saved logins and passwords are compromised in online data breaches. <!-- bug 1565326 -->
 - Complex password generation, to help you create and save strong passwords for new online accounts. <!-- bug 376674 -->


  [1]: https://support.mozilla.org/kb/manage-passwords-firefox-desktop-firefox-lockwise
  [2]: https://support.mozilla.org/products/firefox-lockwise/lockwise-settings
  [3]: https://support.mozilla.org/kb/firefox-lockwise-alerts-breached-websites

Improvements to core engine components, for better browsing on more sites

 - A faster Javascript Baseline Interpreter to handle the modern web’s
   large codebases and improve page load performance by as much as 8
   percent.
 - WebRender rolled out to [more Firefox for Windows users][1], now available by default on Windows desktops with integrated Intel graphics cards and resolution of 1920x1200 or less) for improved graphics rendering. 
 - [Compositor improvements in Firefox for macOS][2] that reduce power
   consumption, speed up page load by as much as [22 percent][3], and reduce
   resource use for video by up to [37 percent][4].

 


  [1]: https://wiki.mozilla.org/Platform/GFX/WebRender_Where
  [2]: https://mozillagfx.wordpress.com/2019/10/22/dramatically-reduced-power-usage-in-firefox-70-on-macos-with-core-animation/
  [3]: https://treeherder.mozilla.org/perf.html#/compare?originalProject=try&originalRevision=18718d1edd41872634b49cbcaf3fe570ce6ad6a3&newProject=try&newRevision=18ef3e9d206ef3ceb3fec3c4170c844a924d0520&framework=10
  [4]: https://treeherder.mozilla.org/perf.html#/compare?originalProject=mozilla-central&newProject=try&newRevision=3d7adefc36d5d5edae6b144dff82919adbb9339e&framework=10&selectedTimeRange=172800#table-header-2242869665

More browser features to help you get the most out of Firefox products and services

 - A stand-alone Firefox account menu for easy access to Firefox services like Monitor and Send.
 - A message panel accessed from the gift icon in the toolbar that offers a quick overview of new releases and key features.
 - When a website uses your geolocation, an indicator is shown in the
   address bar.   <!-- bug 630614 -->
Built-in Firefox pages now follow the system dark mode preference

[Aliased theme properties have been removed][1], which may affect some themes


  [1]: https://blog.mozilla.org/addons/2019/07/25/upcoming-deprecations-in-firefox-70/
Passwords can now be imported from Chrome on macOS in addition to existing support for Windows
Readability is now greatly improved on under- or overlined texts, including links. The lines will now be interrupted instead of crossing over a glyph.

Improved [privacy and security indicators][1]


  [1]: https://blog.mozilla.org/security/2019/10/15/improved-security-and-privacy-indicators-in-firefox-70/

 - A new crossed-out lock icon will indicate sites delivered via
   insecure HTTP  <!-- bug 1562881 -->
 - The formerly green lock icon is now grey <!-- bug 1572675 -->
 - The Extended Validation (EV) indicator has been moved to the identity
   popup that appears when clicking the lock icon <!-- 1572936 -->

[Developer Information][1]
For additional developer resources from Mozilla, visit our [Mozilla Developer YouTube channel][2] for new videos every week. 


  [1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Mozilla/Firefox/Releases/70
  [2]: https://youtube.com/MozillaDeveloper

The Developer Tools Accessibility panel now includes an audit for keyboard accessibility and a color deficiency simulator for systems with WebRender enabled
<!-- bug1564968 and bug 1564966 -->
Inactive CSS: The Inspector now grays out CSS declarations that don’t affect the selected element and shows a tooltip explaining why -- and even how to fix it.

The new DOM Mutation Breakpoints in Developer Tools allows developers to diagnose when scripts add, remove or update page content. This makes debugging of complex script interactions and dependencies a lot easier.
WebExtensions developers can now inspect browser.storage.local data using the "Addon Debugging" Firefox Developer Tools.

With new [network resource search][1] in Developer Tools, you can quickly find resources based on their request and response data, including headers, cookies and content.


  [1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Tools/Network_Monitor

Some websites or page elements using dynamic JavaScript fail to load. [This can be fixed with a temporary workaround][1].


  [1]: https://support.mozilla.org/kb/some-pages-or-page-elements-fail-load-after-updating

system_requirements:
## Windows

### Operating Systems (32-bit and 64-bit)
 - Windows 7
 - Windows 8
 - Windows 10

### Recommended Hardware
-  Pentium 4 or newer processor that supports SSE2
-  512MB of RAM / 2GB of RAM for the 64-bit version
-  200MB of hard drive space

---

## Mac

### Operating Systems
- macOS 10.9
- macOS 10.10
- macOS 10.11
- macOS 10.12
- macOS 10.13
- macOS 10.14
- macOS 10.15

### Recommended Hardware
- Macintosh computer with an Intel x86 processor
- 512 MB of RAM
- 200 MB hard drive space

---

## GNU/Linux

### Software Requirements

*Please note that GNU/Linux distributors may provide packages for your distribution which have different requirements.*

- Firefox will not run at all without the following libraries or packages:
    - GTK+ 3.4 or higher
    - GLib 2.22 or higher
    - Pango 1.22 or higher
    - X.Org 1.0 or higher (1.7 or higher is recommended)
    - libstdc++ 4.6.1 or higher
- For optimal functionality, we recommend the following libraries or packages:
    - NetworkManager 0.7 or higher
    - DBus 1.0 or higher
    - GNOME 2.16 or higher
    - PulseAudio
text:
Enhanced Tracking Protection (ETP) is on by default on all platforms bringing privacy protections to all our users. With this release, you can now [see the many ways ETP protects you][1] in a Privacy Protections report. 

We'd like to extend a special thank you to all of the [new Mozillians][2] who contributed to this release of Firefox.


  [1]: https://blog.mozilla.org/blog/2019/10/22/latest-firefox-brings-privacy-protections-front-and-center-letting-you-track-the-trackers/
  [2]: https://blog.mozilla.org/community/2019/10/22/firefox-70-new-contributors/
title: Firefox 70.0 Release
